quote.para: Stevens's recalcitrance on tax matters can be better understood if it is appreciated that he came to the bar in 1976 and the first time he filed a tax return after that was 20 years later, in 1996.

speech.para: Again, there is the recent case of Stephen Archer, Senior Counsel, a three-time serial bankrupt who, through a cocktail of legal instruments, including family law property orders, bankruptcy petitions filed by himself and taxation powers, effectively transferred all assets out of the reach of his sole creditor, the Commissioner of Taxation, thus denying the commissioner an accumulated debt of almost $4 million in unpaid taxes to date. Who can forget the deplorable arrogance of Mr Bill Davidson, a barrister who used his family trust to, again, place his assets out of the reach of the Taxation Commissioner, thus denying the payment of any tax debt to the Commonwealth?

Finally, there is the case of Mr John Cummins QC who, staggeringly, failed to lodge a single tax return for 45 years and was finally brought to justice before the courts in 2001. It is again the Ackland story that notes the comments of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, Spigelman CJ, who quite properly remarked:

quote.para: Throughout the four decades he engaged in the rank hypocrisy of advocating that other people should perform their legal obligations, while systematically refusing to perform his own.

talk.start.para: —Order! I am not proposing to deny the member for Lowe the right to continue his speech later but will merely do as I am obliged to do—
—This is a very serious issue.
—and interrupt the debate. The member for Lowe will have more to say when whoever is occupying the chair gives him the call.

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I have a real fear that we are about to face a most worrying crisis in my own electorate of Bass, in other parts of Tasmania and, I suspect, in many other areas of Australia. My concern is that we will have insufficient housing to provide roofs over the heads of significant numbers of Australian families.
—Not the state government again!

—I believe that we are only a very short period of time away from the problem manifesting itself in a very substantial manner. I only wish the Minister for Employment Services had the decency to care about this issue rather than make snide comments. We have had families coming into my electorate office, with good references and with the capacity to pay more than reasonable rents, unable to find accommodation. As one provider told me, `We can't get model families into housing, let alone single parent families with loads of debt.'

speech.para: How has this come about? The problem is that a whole range of factors have unfortunately coincided. Firstly, we had the first home owners grant. Whilst it was and is a good scheme in terms of allowing young Australians, in particular, to set off along the path of buying their own home, it does have a downside. In Tasmania, in particular, because of a combination of lower prices and a low stock of available housing, the presence of the grant has caused the removal of many properties from the lower end of the rental market. This is unfortunate, but it is a fact. We are also experiencing, probably for the first time in the history of our state, a real estate boom. Houses and shacks which were selling a year or two ago for under $40,000 are now going for up to 10 times that price. Stories are common of mainland buyers briefing real estate agents to purchase up to 10 housing properties for them, often sight unseen.

This has particularly affected rural towns, where the low prices have proved particularly attractive to non-Tasmanians suddenly captivated by the potential we have always known that we have. Whilst this certainly has an upside in terms of general economic activity and for those with properties to sell, it has the opposite for those desperate for a roof over their head. The investors are buying seaside properties, mostly as retirement homes or weekenders, and driving up rentals as well as affecting the availability of cheaper housing to purchase.

Anecdotal evidence indicates that rents in my electorate have risen by up to 25 per cent in the past 12 months. Poverty levels have thus been increasing, even for people in stable housing arrangements. There has been a 70 percent increase in waiting lists. As I said previously, I am fearful that this is really just the beginning of our crisis. In our relatively small population we have had more than 750 families waiting for public housing. Many of them currently have nowhere to live apart from the garages, farm sheds or cars that they or their friends may own. Because of our warm summer, many have chosen the temporary solution of living in tents or tent-like accommodation in friends' backyards. In the Tasmanian winter, that soon will not be an option.

Whilst the general housing shortage is a relatively new problem, we have experienced already for many years a lack of crisis accommodation, particularly for men. Their problems will rise exponentially as a result of these other developments. It has also been difficult to get people with high and complex needs into private rentals. Now it is going to be virtually impossible to achieve that. At the same time, the state government has been forced to sell off stock because of its condition—because its use-by date has come around—but, frankly, this could not have come at a worse time. There is simply not enough funding coming back into the system through sales and other sources to fund the need. Even where there are dollars available to invest in housing, we are running into another problem: lack of builders, contractors, tradespeople and apprentices.

How are we going to fix it? As we have heard from both political commentators and state premiers over the past week, it is certainly not going to come from a squabble between the Commonwealth and the state and territory governments. The situation demands a cooperative approach at all levels and solutions that will break the poverty cycle and the ever increasing problem of disadvantage. We have to, as a complete priority, increase the supply of housing and break the backs of the waiting lists. Some quite innovative ways have been suggested. I think that we, as members of parliament, have an obligation to investigate all of those, even those that have only the slightest chance of success, because this problem is not going to go away if we simply bury our heads in the sand.

The provision of housing is probably one of the most basic needs that we, as a fair and just society, provide to members of our community in order to allow them to achieve their full potential. We cannot demand of people that they participate actively in society if we cannot even ensure that they have somewhere to live. Governments at all levels will simply have to make a commitment to provide funds and incentives so that safe and appropriate housing—the provision of a roof over everyone's head—becomes amongst the highest of all priorities.

talk.start.para: —When I was first elected to this chamber, I took great pride in the fact that I could stand up for, represent and be a voice for the people of Moncrieff. A message that was delivered loud and clear to me throughout my campaign was that on the Gold Coast there was a very definite need for more police. It is a great shame that the Queensland state Labor government and the police minister in Queensland, the Hon. Tony McGrady, turn their ears away and are deaf to the demands of the people of the Gold Coast for more police. At that time, I thought that there was a real chance that the Queensland state government would respond. In part, to give them credit, they did respond. They responded with the promise of an additional 69 police.

speech.para: There are two important issues that have now come to my attention that again underscore the very real need for the Gold Coast to have more police. The first is a series of headlines in recent newspapers, such as `We're Not Safe', the headline that screamed from the Gold Coast Sun. It went to great lengths to talk about how high-ranking police officers, under the cover of anonymity, were highlighting to the media that they could not guarantee not only public safety but the safety of police officers that were working on the beat. What is the response of the Queensland police minister to all of this? The Queensland police minister's response is: `There's a formula in place, and that formula says that there's enough police on the Gold Coast.' One could ask: what is the position of the seven state Labor MPs on the Gold Coast? The position is that they also feel that there are enough police on the Gold Coast, but it is fundamentally wrong. I know it and the 450,000 people of the Gold Coast know it. They know it because the Gold Coast continues to have the highest crime rate in the state of Queensland.

This formula does not apply to the Gold Coast, and the reason it does not apply is that the Gold Coast has some unique needs. Principally, it is an event based tourism capital. Events such as Schoolies Week and Indy car week bring a throng of people to the Gold Coast, many of whom are unfortunately in a drunken state after attending what is a very popular nightclub strip. The problem is that the Queensland government do not take into account that our very hardworking, very loyal Queensland police quite frankly are under-resourced and not in a position to cope with the influx of people that occurs around these major events. State Labor members—and I would highlight the member for Gaven, Robert Poole, a former police officer—came out and said, `No, we don't need more police at all; it is quite to the contrary.' It is absolutely incredible. This is the attitude from a state government that quite clearly have become so arrogant about law and order that they will turn away from the fact that, in responses to the 240,000 surveys that I have distributed in my electorate, the No. 1 issue each and every time is law and order. Quite frankly, it is not enough for the Queensland state government to say, `Well, we'll throw a couple of additional police at the problem and hope that fixes it up.'

Another thing that has come to my attention and that concerns me gravely is that the promise the state government made to allocate an additional 69 police to the Gold Coast may be a very hollow promise. It has been brought to my attention that this allocation of 69 additional police may be for only one year. They will put the new constables onto the Gold Coast to train them up, with every intention of then transferring them to other locations within the state of Queensland at the end of that 12-month period. If this is true, it highlights not only the arrogance of the Queensland state Labor government but also the extent to which they will engage in this smoke and mirrors trick to try to deceive the people of the Gold Coast and to try to say that they are responding to a problem that quite clearly is not being dealt with. The question I want answered by the Queensland state police minister is: are those additional police guaranteed to stay on the Gold Coast from the point they are transferred there onwards? It is a basic request and it is a request that the Queensland police minister, if he is honest enough with the people of the Gold Coast, should respond to. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Labor have always been the party of innovation. We have always sought to improve and build on the successes of the past. We have always looked to the future and developed our policies on that basis. I would hate to think of the number of times I have said in this place that children are our future and that we as a parliament must do our best to put in place policies that nourish their growth and provide for their future. It gives me a great deal of pleasure, therefore, to be able to talk about the latest discussion paper produced by the Labor shadow ministry. Growing up—investing in the early years has been developed by the shadow minister for children and youth, my colleague the member for Gellibrand. This is the 12th discussion paper released by the ALP shadow ministry in the past eight months.

speech.para: We know from the McCain and Mustard 1999 study Reversing the real brain drain that 75 per cent of a child's brain develops during the first five years of their life and that half of all the intellectual and developmental potential of a child is established by age four. If we want to create the best possible future for a child, these early years are vital and programs need to be targeted to ensure the best possible outcomes. Research shows that quality early childhood programs significantly reduce learning problems later in life, can tip the balance later on and keep a young person off welfare and away from juvenile justice, and have so many other positive effects. Quality lifelong learning, starting with early childhood, creates a positive influence throughout a person's life. Good education leads to better employment outcomes. Unfortunately, Australia spends only 0.1 per cent of our gross domestic product on early education and care. This means that, out of the 28 OECD countries, Australia ranks a paltry 26th. We need to lift our game. Although it got lost in the fear and smear campaign of the 2001 election, Labor took to that election a $264 million policy package of early childhood and family initiatives. We had the commitment then and we still have the commitment today.

As the discussion paper points out, it is clear from all the experiences, both here in Australia and internationally, that all the good work done in this area by individuals, governments and community organisations alike is being undermined and hampered because there is not a clear national framework to work within. There needs to be a partnership between all levels of government and community based organisations that is based on the following principles: one, a comprehensive approach to early childhood development that includes early childhood education, child care and parenting or care-giving support; two, universally available and accessible programs; three, integration of programs across education, social services and health sectors, along with integration of funding streams from different levels of government; four, design and delivery of programs driven at the local level in order to be responsive to local needs and involve representation from all relevant sectors, including the voluntary sectors; and, five, standards of practice developed to ensure the quality of all programs. Those are five simple principles to work by, five simple principles to provide the best future for our children. Labor recognise them, and our policies will be developed with them in mind.

As with all other policies Labor has released in the past 12 months—that is, the nine policy papers and the 12 discussion papers—this one, Growing up—investing in the early years, can be downloaded from my web site at www.nswalp.com/frankmoss-field. I want to congratulate the shadow minister on all her hard work in this area. Already, she has released the policies outlining Labor's call for a commissioner for children and youth. Now we have this discussion paper, which outlines the principles by which our policy on early childhood learning will be guided; one of the most fundamental policy areas for building a brighter future. An investment in our children will take many years to bear fruit. There is no quick return and no fast buck, but let me tell you that it is well worth the effort.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to bring unfortunate situations to the attention of the House. Whenever anyone loses their employment it is an unfortunate situation. It is no less unfortunate that in my electorate of Kalgoorlie, specifically in the town of Esperance, a number of Western Australian government employees in the agriculture department are losing their positions because the Labor government in the state is strapped for cash.

speech.para: But the concerns that I have centre primarily on the fact that the Western Australian agriculture minister is calling on the federal government to come good with funds from the national action plan on salinity. I am disturbed because one of the core concerns of the provision of funding under the national action plan for salinity is that the Commonwealth funding not be provided for direct employment of state government employees. After many months of negotiation with the Commonwealth government—the state having attested that never would these funds, if received, be used for the employment of state employees—we now have the state Minister for Agriculture demanding that the Commonwealth pay up to support the employees of the state government.

It is an absolute contradiction of the terms of agreement that all other state premiers and the Northern Territory have signed off on. It is an agreement that allows funds to flow from the taxpayers of the Commonwealth to the states—to support the national action plan for salinity. The Western Australian government have put a proposition to the Commonwealth suggesting that they would support a total of $80 million being used to treat the salinity problems in Western Australia. And goodness knows, Western Australia has a lot of problems with salinity. The amount of land that has been cleared and subsequently farmed in Western Australia is suffering degradation as a result of rising salinity.

The national plan to confront this salinity calls on new projects—new state money—to confront the problem. The Commonwealth is calling on the Western Australian government to sign off on a contract whereby the Western Australian government will provide dollar-for-dollar funding for new action plans to treat salinity. It seems that the Western Australian Minister for Agriculture cannot come to grips with the fact that he should agree to a strategy that has been agreed to by all other state ministers and the Northern Territory. He believes that he can put up commercial propositions funded by the Western Australian government and have those funds subsidised dollar-for-dollar by the taxpayers of the Commonwealth. He believes that he can reafforest and treat the salinity of the Wellington Dam catchment area and be reimbursed by the national taxpayers with federal funds.

This is not a reasonable deal and he should have no reasonable expectation that the Commonwealth will sign off on such a contract. He should not, furthermore, use the lack of signing off on this contract by the Commonwealth as an excuse for sacking employees of the Western Australian agriculture department. I am amazed that after some 18 months of negotiation—and his declaring to the Commonwealth government that these federal funds would never, ever be used for the support of state employees—he would suddenly go public with the declaration that if it were not for the tardiness of the Commonwealth government in providing these funds, state employees would maintain their jobs.

I think that it is time that the Western Australian government, strapped for cash as they are, stop blaming the federal government for not providing those funds necessary to maintain employment in the state government sector and declare the correct situation: that they are asking the Commonwealth to sign off on a contract which would be contrary to the agreement signed off on by all other state governments and the Northern Territory, to fight the salinity situation in the Australian Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Eureka flag and the recognition of this important symbol under the Flags Act 1953. To commemorate the 148th anniversary of the battle at the Eureka Stockade I wrote to you, Mr Speaker, and the President of the Senate, requesting that the flag be flown from a suitable flagpole in the Parliament House precinct.
—What rubbish!

—I was advised that as the Eureka flag is not proclaimed under the Flags Act 1953, it could not be flown—a precedent which, I might add, has not always been followed. I then wrote to the Prime Minister seeking his support to proclaim this important Australian emblem. Six or so weeks later I received a reply from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, the federal member for Fisher, who wrote:

quote.para: While the Eureka flag is an important flag in Australia's history, it does not, like the many flags or ensigns in use in Australia, come within the ambit of the Flags Act, which is intended to cover only those flags which represent the nation, its people or government.

speech.para: What an insult to those who sacrificed their lives during the uprising and the descendants of those who were at Eureka—the children of Eureka.

talk.start.para: —I do not hear them.

—They represent the very spirit and heart of this nation. There were over 20 nations represented on the goldfields and at least 17 at Eureka, the place which many people consider to be the birthplace of Australian democracy. The Eureka uprising is widely acknowledged as an important step on Australia's road to nationhood. It is an event that should be commemorated and recognised. The original flag, hand sewn by the women of Eureka, is still in Ballarat today. Somewhat worse for wear, it is an incredible sight. I would encourage those members on the other side who are mocking this issue to come and have a look at it. I try to take every visitor I have in Ballarat to see the flag. It is truly a remarkable sight.

speech.para: The battle at the Eureka Stockade on 3 December 1854 was a defining moment in Australia's development as a nation. The Eureka rebellion was a revolution, a struggle for principle and a stand against injustice and oppression—it was the birthplace of Australian democracy. The concerns underlying the discontent on the goldfields at the time are themes that still carry important meanings for today's Australians: human rights, democracy, no taxation without representation, and national identity. It is those issues that give the Eureka rebellion its significance to the nation.

It is worth noting that the Eureka flag has been considered significant enough to be flown on the anniversary of the uprising in the precinct of the Victorian state parliament for several years and in the New South Wales state parliament for the first time last year. It has previously flown from the federal parliament. It would be a great shame if the Eureka flag were not able to be flown in the parliamentary precinct during the commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Eureka uprising in 2004.

Ballarat is proud of our Eureka heritage. It is now time for the federal government to truly recognise the importance of the Eureka uprising to the development of our nation by proclaiming the Eureka flag under the Flags Act. I suspect, from the mocking comments coming from the other side of the House, that this is a forlorn hope, but I encourage a spirit of bipartisanship in the desire for recognition of the Eureka flag under the Flags Act 1953.

The member for Deakin was in my electorate during the 148th anniversary of the Eureka uprising and he was extremely supportive, unlike some other members in the House at the moment, of the flag being proclaimed. Malcolm Fraser is also a patron of Eureka, and I understand that he would also like to see it recognised. I hope that, in a spirit of bipartisanship, we can begin to understand the importance of the Eureka flag in Australia's history, be proud of it and fly it from this parliament on the 150th anniversary.

talk.start.para: —I have some really terrific news for the parliament: I am going to tell the House tonight what this government is doing for education in my electorate. It is just tremendous. It is about time the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, got his act together, put his action where his mouth is and increased funding to education in New South Wales at the same rate as the Commonwealth is increasing funding to both government and non-government schools.

speech.para: Listen to this growth in new apprenticeship commencements in Mitchell; it is fabulous. In 1999-2000 there were 1,096 new apprentices in Mitchell. Last year there were 1,745—an increase of 75 per cent in just two years. The funds allocated to the new apprenticeship incentive grew from $1.53 million to $2.16 million in the same period. I turn to higher education. We have a wonderful campus of the Western Sydney Institute of TAFE. In 2002 New South Wales received approximately 337 million Commonwealth dollars, plus indexation through the National Training Authority.

I now turn to schools, because they are so significant. I have one of the greatest youth populations in the nation in the electorate of Mitchell. First of all, I will look at capital grants. I will deal with non-government schools first. In 1996, capital grants to non-government schools were $730,000; there were none in 1997, but in 1998 they totalled $150,000; in 1999, they were $400,000; and in 2000, $250,000—a total over the period 1996-2002 of $1.53 million. I turn to government schools. This is a government that the Labor Party would have you believe hates government schools. I am a product of a government school.

talk.start.para: —So am I.

—So is the minister at the table. We are proud of government schools. Listen to this for a far-sighted and committed government. In 1996, $1.45 million went to government schools; in 1997, $400,000; in 1998, $3.4 million; in 1999, zero; in 2000, $3.5 million; in 2001, $1.4 million; and, in 2002, $10.8 million—a total over that period of $21.12 million to build schools in the electorate of Mitchell. In the same period, non-government schools—and the growth has been as significant—received $1.5 million.
—It is 10 to one.

—It is more like 20 to one. There is favouritism towards government schools' capital growth in the electorate of Mitchell. The state governments pay the salaries in government schools, and the Commonwealth pays the recurrent grants in non-government schools. Of course, there is a large salary component—$157.8 million—in the non-government schools in Mitchell. I want to mention some of these schools because they are just fabulous and it is a joy to go to them. Baulkham Hills High School received $845,000 over two years to build a new auditorium.

speech.para: Beaumont Hills Primary School received $3.75 million to build the new school. I was there for the opening, and John Aquilina—no wonder he is not minister anymore—came and claimed the benefit of paying for that school for the state government. It was all Commonwealth money. I was generous to John on the day and I regret that I was—but he is a nice bloke. I think he probably lost that portfolio because he did not acknowledge the Commonwealth sufficiently.

Castle Hill Public School received $3.4 million. Kellyville High School, a brand new high school, received $9.5 million in 2001-02. Kellyville Public School received $1.8 million. North Rocks Public School received $500,000. Rouse Hill Public School received $1.2 million. As I have already mentioned, smaller amounts went to such non-government schools as Arndell College, Lorien Novalis, Marian College, and the William Branwhite Clarke College in Kellyville. It just goes to show that this government has its priorities and its spending right. It knows where the kids are, it wants to support families and education, and it is fairly distributing funds to both government and non-government schools. The state governments need to pull their weight. Bob Carr needs to acknowledge that he is not doing his job properly. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.
